pt.runtime

Class TaskIDGroup<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • pt.runtime.TaskID<T>
      • pt.runtime.TaskIDGroup<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - 

    public class TaskIDGroup<T>
extends TaskID<T>
    An extension of TaskID to contain multiple tasks. In particular, a TaskIDGroup is returned for all multi-task invocations. Users may also instantiate a TaskIDGroup and populate it with multiple TaskIDs (and TaskIDGroups). This would be useful, for example, when invoking many different tasks, allowing a collective approach to synchronise on those tasks (i.e. wait on the TaskIDGroup rather than the on each individual TaskID.
    Author:
    Nasser Giacaman, Oliver Sinnen

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      TaskIDGroup() 
      TaskIDGroup(int groupSize)
      This public constructor is actually used to group a bunch of tasks, which may include one-off task or multi task, should not give any id to this group.

    • Method Detail

      • addInnerTask

        public void addInnerTask(TaskID<T> taskID)
        Since:
        10/05/2013 Do not set relative id here. Instead, before a TaskID is added into a group, a relative id should be given first. However if do not set relative id here, when trying to add a TaskID into a user defined group, this TaskID become untraceable through relative id. It still can be traced through its global id. Because of the same reason, do not set part of group here. Instead, set part of group when a multi task is expanded just like set relative id there. Maybe a good idea that only allow to call this method paratask runtime internally, which means it is used for multi task group only but not user defined group.

        public void setInnerTask(int relativeID,

      • getReturnResult

        public T getReturnResult()
        Get the result of a group of tasks. To use this method, an instance of a reduction operation must be passed to the TaskID constructor, otherwise use getReturnResult(Reduction).
        Overrides:
        getReturnResult in class TaskID<T>
        Returns:
        The result of the task.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        See Also:
        getReturnResult(Reduction), getInnerTaskResult(int)

      • getResultsAsArray

        public T[] getResultsAsArray(T[] array)
        This method is specifically useful for retrieving the results of the sub-tasks of a future group. Individual tasks may depend on a future group, and require the entire array of that future group, in order to perform their operation. For example, an asynchronous task that reduces the result of a future group when the future group is finished.
        Returns:
        T[] an array that represents the results of the sub-tasks of this future group.
        Since:
        2017

      • getReturnResult

        public T getReturnResult(pu.RedLib.Reduction<T> reductionOperation)
        Performs customized reductions on the results contained in the group. This is a one-off operation, and the specified reduction is not memorized as the group's reduction operation.
        Parameters:
        reductionOperation - The reduction to perform on the results of the contained TaskIDs
        Returns:
        The result after performing the specified reduction.
        Throws:
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • getTaskInfo

        public TaskInfo<T> getTaskInfo()

      • setException

        public void setException(java.lang.Throwable exception)
        This method is called by one of the inner tasks when it incurs an exception. Therefore, the group knows that there is an exception within the group that needs handling.
        Parameters:
        exception - The exception instance that has been encountered by an inner task.
        Since:
        19/8/2015

      • setReturnResult

        public void setReturnResult(java.lang.Object returnResult)

      • cancelAttempt

        public boolean cancelAttempt()
        Canceling a group is currently not supported. Users must cancel each inner task individually.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException

      • waitTillFinished

        public void waitTillFinished()
                      throws java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException,
                             java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits for all the contained inner tasks to complete. It goes through all inner-tasks and if an inner-task is a TaskIDGroup, which means there is another multi-task inside the group waits until that inner multi-task is expanded and all its task are finished. Then, it proceeds to finishe other inner-tasks. If an inner-task is a TaskID, which means it is a normal task, wait until that task is completed.
        Overrides:
        waitTillFinished in class TaskID<T>
        Throws:
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException
        java.lang.InterruptedException
        Since:
        08/05/2013, 9/9/2014

      • setExpanded

        protected void setExpanded(boolean isExpanded)
        Since:
        08/05/2013 After a multi task worker thread expand a multi-task, call this method to set a "true" value.

        protected boolean isExpanded()
